update.description:
This pull request along with it's sister pull requests introduces qtutil's new abstraction layer for Qt. This abstraction layer is supposed to act like PyQt5. A few adjustments needed to be made so things don't break.

This pull request should also bring PyQt5 compatibility but this should be experimental at first so reviewing should not include this as a criterium for approval. (This has been discussed [here](https://pstarkey.github.io/bitbucket-archive/#!/pull-requests/1/pyqt5/diff#comment-41775691))

To test this one needs to also pull from my qtutils repo [here](https://bitbucket.org/PhyNerd/qtutils/).
update.title: qtutils 2.0.0 support and experimental PyQt5 support

content.raw: I've verified communication with child processes works - I've been 'running experiments' with the dummy pseudoclock device. I also have a patch to the PulseBlaster device file that mocks calls to the spinapi, and I've run that too with no pulseblaster actually present, and the status checks during manual mode worked.
content.html: I've verified communication with child processes works - I've been 'running experiments' with the dummy pseudoclock device. I also have a patch to the PulseBlaster device file that mocks calls to the spinapi, and I've run that too with no pulseblaster actually present, and the status checks during manual mode worked.

content.raw: Can we log QT_ENV as well in `__main__.py`? I know we should be able to infer it from the version string, but let's log it just to be safe (and also this makes it forward compatible if PySide suddenly ramps up version numbers or something so they aren't distinct from PyQt)
content.html: Can we log QT_ENV as well in __main__.py? I know we should be able to infer it from the version string, but let's log it just to be safe (and also this makes it forward compatible if PySide suddenly ramps up version numbers or something so they aren't distinct from PyQt)

content.raw:
Aha, sorry I wasn't paying enough attention. show() can be called multiple times with no ill effect, so that's alright, then the only issue is if another plugin wants the GUI to not be shown yet.

Does it work if you do:
```
show()
setStyleSheet()
hide()
```
?

I would prefer if it wasn't one specific plugin responsible for when show() was called, if plugins can leave things the way they found them other than the things they are explicitly changing, then that would be ideal, if possible!
content.html:
Aha, sorry I wasn't paying enough attention. show() can be called multiple times with no ill effect, so that's alright, then the only issue is if another plugin wants the GUI to not be shown yet.

Does it work if you do:

show()
setStyleSheet()
hide()

?

I would prefer if it wasn't one specific plugin responsible for when show() was called, if plugins can leave things the way they found them other than the things they are explicitly changing, then that would be ideal, if possible!

content.raw:
then I would rather opt with my first approche adding 
```
#!python

self.BLACS['ui'].centralwidget.show()
```
before the stylesheet. This is just one line of code and the slot stuff is way more. Also I see no downside in this the behavior doesn't seem to change in the slightest with the show there or not.
content.html:
then I would rather opt with my first approche adding

pull_request.title: qtutils 2.0.0 support and experimental PyQt5 support

pullrequest.title: qtutils 2.0.0 support and experimental PyQt5 support

content.raw:
So the existing stylesheet (which we pull out as self.unmodified_stylesheet ) is set in Qt designer. I'm guessing that the Ui loader changed such that this setting is now set on the widget upon first show - meaning that it would overwrite what we had set prior to the show(). But I'm not sure about that, and it's a hypothesis that could be checked.

I also tried `self.BLACS['ui']setStyleSheet(self.unmodified_stylesheet + stylesheet_settings)` and I think I recall it not being quite right - because `self.BLACS['ui']` is higher in the hierarchy than the `centralWidget`, and so the flat buttons theme was set on the `centralWidget`, overriding some of the settings and  leading to the green buttons being grey when pushed in or moused-over or something, if I recall. 

The time at which plugin_setup_complete is called is not so easy to change - other plugins certainly need to be able to set up before the GUI is shown.

How about hooking up a slot that sets the initial theme to a firstPaint() signal on the main window similar to how we defer some things until first paint in lyse and runmanager? plugin_setup_complete can connect the slot to do the work that it wants to defer until then.
content.html:
So the existing stylesheet (which we pull out as self.unmodified_stylesheet ) is set in Qt designer. I'm guessing that the Ui loader changed such that this setting is now set on the widget upon first show - meaning that it would overwrite what we had set prior to the show(). But I'm not sure about that, and it's a hypothesis that could be checked.

I also tried self.BLACS['ui']setStyleSheet(self.unmodified_stylesheet + stylesheet_settings) and I think I recall it not being quite right - because self.BLACS['ui'] is higher in the hierarchy than the centralWidget, and so the flat buttons theme was set on the centralWidget, overriding some of the settings and leading to the green buttons being grey when pushed in or moused-over or something, if I recall.

The time at which plugin_setup_complete is called is not so easy to change - other plugins certainly need to be able to set up before the GUI is shown.

How about hooking up a slot that sets the initial theme to a firstPaint() signal on the main window similar to how we defer some things until first paint in lyse and runmanager? plugin_setup_complete can connect the slot to do the work that it wants to defer until then.

pull_request.title: qtutils 2.0.0 support and experimental PyQt5 support

pullrequest.title: qtutils 2.0.0 support and experimental PyQt5 support

content.raw:
Ok so I can reproduce this bug.I'll try and fix it and as usual update here.

Update: Ok so adding

```
#!python

self.BLACS['ui'].centralwidget.show()
```

 before the setStyleSheet solves it. I'm guessing stylesheets can only be set in pyqt5 when the widget is already displayed. So we can move the plugin so after show is called in BLACS, use this or find a better fix. I'll do some googeling maybe I find someone else with this problem.

Update2: I couldn't find anything on this topic. I'll do some testing with minimal examples to see if this is a BLACS or PyQt5 problem

Update3: Seems to be a BLACS only problem minimal app just creating a window and button allows style sheets before show

Update4: Moving the plugin_setup_complete section of main behind show also solves the problem. And if we wanted to apply the stylesheet to all of BLACS that would work as well. Meaning replacing """self.BLACS['ui'].centralwidget.setStyleSheet(self.unmodified_stylesheet + stylesheet_settings)""" with """self.BLACS['ui']setStyleSheet(self.unmodified_stylesheet + stylesheet_settings)"""

So thats 3 solutions I would say moving the plugin_setup_complete section is the cleanest
content.html:
Ok so I can reproduce this bug.I'll try and fix it and as usual update here.

Update: Ok so adding

self.BLACS['ui'].centralwidget.show()

before the setStyleSheet solves it. I'm guessing stylesheets can only be set in pyqt5 when the widget is already displayed. So we can move the plugin so after show is called in BLACS, use this or find a better fix. I'll do some googeling maybe I find someone else with this problem.

Update2: I couldn't find anything on this topic. I'll do some testing with minimal examples to see if this is a BLACS or PyQt5 problem

Update3: Seems to be a BLACS only problem minimal app just creating a window and button allows style sheets before show

Update4: Moving the plugin_setup_complete section of main behind show also solves the problem. And if we wanted to apply the stylesheet to all of BLACS that would work as well. Meaning replacing """self.BLACS['ui'].centralwidget.setStyleSheet(self.unmodified_stylesheet + stylesheet_settings)""" with """self.BLACS['ui']setStyleSheet(self.unmodified_stylesheet + stylesheet_settings)"""

So thats 3 solutions I would say moving the plugin_setup_complete section is the cleanest

content.raw: I definitely saw a Qstring containing a camera port number being rejected by an unpickler on the other end of a zeromq connection with a complaint about both Qt5 and Qt4 being imported - it didn't make much sense to me because although I can see that the camera port number is being read from a QLabel (!) before sending it to the worker, I thought that that should have resulted in a Python string, not a QString. So there's something going on there.
content.html: I definitely saw a Qstring containing a camera port number being rejected by an unpickler on the other end of a zeromq connection with a complaint about both Qt5 and Qt4 being imported - it didn't make much sense to me because although I can see that the camera port number is being read from a QLabel (!) before sending it to the worker, I thought that that should have resulted in a Python string, not a QString. So there's something going on there.

content.raw: This is almost certainly one or more of the plugins. I had to do some horrible hacks to support both PyQt4 and PySide, but that was when we were using the V1 API. It will all need updating I suspect due to the change in API (and more importantly, may actually be broken now under PyQt4 as well)
content.html: This is almost certainly one or more of the plugins. I had to do some horrible hacks to support both PyQt4 and PySide, but that was when we were using the V1 API. It will all need updating I suspect due to the change in API (and more importantly, may actually be broken now under PyQt4 as well)

content.raw: Are you sure that's not labscript_devices importing PyQt5 when BLACS is PyQt4? Since they both are imported in the same interpreter that would definitely cause issues. I've been seeing that - goes away if I switch labscript_devices back to PyQt4 as well.
content.html: Are you sure that's not labscript_devices importing PyQt5 when BLACS is PyQt4? Since they both are imported in the same interpreter that would definitely cause issues. I've been seeing that - goes away if I switch labscript_devices back to PyQt4 as well.

content.html: I'll look into it tonight as I've also noticed another problem in BLACS. Sometimes when switching between PyQt4 and PYQt5 I can't load BLACS because of some setting saving Qt objects I think but I'm not sure. I wanted to learn more about how BLACS functions anyway :)

content.raw: There is a problem that only appears with PyQt5 - the loading of the green button theme doesn't seem to be working. If you go into the settings menu and click ok on the theme tab, then it applies it just fine - but not at startup. I'm not sure why, since it's the same code running in both cases. I'll look into it at some point.
content.html: There is a problem that only appears with PyQt5 - the loading of the green button theme doesn't seem to be working. If you go into the settings menu and click ok on the theme tab, then it applies it just fine - but not at startup. I'm not sure why, since it's the same code running in both cases. I'll look into it at some point.
